newsitem.title: LITHUANIA: OSCE says Lithuania elections badly organised.
newsitem.headline: OSCE says Lithuania elections badly organised.

text.p: International observers on Tuesday said Lithuania's weekend parliamentary elections were badly organised, putting so much strain on the voting system that some irregularities took place.
Results from the Sunday polls, won by Vytautas Landsbergis's Homeland Union, came painfully slowly and the first figures were delayed by many hours.
A final tally had not been declared on Tuesday, more than 36 hours after the polls closed.
The Lithuanian electoral committee blamed a new computer system and the fact that voters had to make several choices on their ballot papers.

"Sunday's elections here were free and fair but technical problems caused many deviations and irregularities," said Frank Aarebrot, head of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) mission observing the vote.
"The deviations were not intentional or fraudulent. We observed no cases of intimidation or manipulation. They were the product of poor organisation and technical problems," he told Reuters.
He also said that not enough voting booths or polling stations were provided.

Lithuanians on Sunday were voting for two party lists, one of candidates chosen by proportional representation and one by a majority vote. They also had to answer three questions in two separate referendums.
Aarebrot said that people tired of waiting in queues started filling out their forms before entering the polling booth, meaning their vote could be seen by other people.
"Open voting was a voluntary response to the circumstances in this election. Next time, there could be voter manipulation," he said.
